lines.text: What's that green slime you're eating? It looks like a dish out of Oliver Twist.
I'm not sure... I think they run the front lawn through a blender.
You're worse than a hopeless romantic. You're a hopeful one.
We should never have come. I never know how to dress in this bloody country. It is so easy to dress in England. You just put on warm clothing.
[getting ready for Oscar ceremony]
Say something *nice* to me Sidney! I've been getting ready for this horseshit affair for *three hours!*
I suppose if Jenny stays she'll grow up to look like that. Blonde hair. Blonde teeth. Blonde life.
You drank everything in this state. Try Nevada!
One day when you're an antique I shall vote for you. I promise.
Screw the Oscars. Screw the Academy Awards. Screw me, Sidney. Please. Please.
How much would you say she is, Marvin? Does she look like a fifty dollar hooker to you?
I don't know... I guess so...
What a cheap brother you've got. We spend a HUNDRED AND SEVENTY-FIVE on his lousy kid!

[after he kisses her]
Don't close your eyes, Sidney.
I always close my eyes.
Not tonight. Look at me tonight. Let it be me tonight.
[first lines]
[a two-seater plane is flying over snow-capped mountains]
For heaven's sake, Wendy - look for an airport. Will you look for the airport?
Oh don't make such a fuss. Just put it down on a mountain.
What do you mean 'just put it down'? I'm lucky I can keep it up. I told you I never flew before.
Don't shout at me - I'm a first-class passenger.
You're a first class lunatic. It's all over Wendy - our relationship has a quarter of a tank to go.
Yes, but - you do love me, don't you Harold? I know this is an awkward time to bring it up, but I must know, for our future.
[plane suddenly plummets]
Whoa-a-a-a!
[last lines]

Good afternoon ladies and gentlemen. Welcome aboard Flight 211 to New York and London. Our flying time this afternoon will be four hours and fifty minutes and we'll be cruising at an altitude of 37,000 feet. We'll now be serving you cocktails and beverages and then serving lunch, followed by our film 'No Left Turn' starring James Coburn and Diana Barrie.
Oh Christ! Sidney, let's get off. Tell them to let us off this bloody plane.
I am going to bed. We have a 10 a.m. plane to catch in the morning.
10 a.m. is the morning. That is redundant, you A.H.
Oh, do you think I don't know what you're saying? I *can* spell, you know.
Not without moving your lips, you can't.

[on the Academy Awards]
Why do they have these things so early? I mean, no woman can look good at 5 o'clock in the afternoon. Except, possibly Tatum O'Neal.
When you haven't seen your ex-husband in nine years, your eyes have to... adjust.
You look so... what is the word?
Happy.

[ignores his reply]
Casual.
Fit? You think I look fit? You awful shit, I look gorgeous!
You drive everywhere, do you?
Everywhere.
Even to your car?
And I gave up analysis.
I heard that. Why did you quit?
I went sane.
Mate-wise? Mate-wise I'm seeing a very nice girl.
Are you? Seeing her to where?
Jenny is our daughter. Ours.
Maybe. We'll see. They've been a little slow with the blood tests.
With Nixon in the White House, good health seemed to be in bad taste.
Your friend is a size too small for me.
[inspects bathing suit]
How does she fit you?
No.
No, what?
No, sir.
Do you really think she has that devious a mind?
Of course - she's my daughter.
You're not the same woman I left nine years ago.
And I have the missing ovaries to prove it!
They will think that we are still mad for each other after twelve years.
Oh, I thought we were. I keep forgetting.
That's not funny Sidney - that's bizarre!
I won't get pissed until after I lose.
What do you do with your afternoon... Sidney?
In London? I don't think we have afternoon.

[angrily]
I'm not asking you - I'm threatening you, you crud!
Now I'm definitely not going to tell you.

[sincerely]
I'm sorry - I take it back Sidney, you're not a crud!
Am I still an asshole?
Definitely!
I look like I was hit by a fully-loaded, guided tour bus.
There is never anything personal between us, is there? Or is that going too personal?
The only think you don't do in your dressing room is dress.
I don't follow other people's films. I barely follow yours.
I've never seen you so sex-crazed in the morning!
I never realized that it was the morning.
Do you know who that is?
Yes, it's our hooker. Do you think I would ride with strangers?
vulnerable.
Well, take a picture of it, 'cause you're not going to see it again.

[Marvin is in town for his nephew's bar mitzvah. His brother has set him up with a hooker, who is in his bed, unconscious, when Marvin's wife, Millie, arrives. Marvin tries desperately to keep her from seeing the hooker, but finally gives in to the inevitable]
Millie... I want you to turn around. But please - no matter what you see - don't say anything for ten seconds.
[Millie turns. She sees the unconscious hooker]
One... two... I'm praying, Marvin. I'm praying very hard the maid came in here to do your room, got dizzy, and fainted from overwork. I'm praying to God the maids in this hotel wear pajamas.
[during an argument after the awards]
Faggot.
Oh, good. I thought you'd never ask.
If we're going to banter like this give me a minute. After nine years I'm a little rusty.
Oh, don't worry. You'll pick it right up again. It's like french. See, that's what I'd miss if I ever left New York. The bantering.
San Francisco's only an hour away. we go up there and banter in emergencies.
I never liked San Francisco. I was always afraid I'd fall out of bed and roll down one of those hills.
Not you, Hannah. You roll up hills.
Oh, good. You're bantering; the flight out wasn't a total loss.
Channel 12 just called you the dark horse. They must have seen the dress.
You hate it.
How much was it?
Nothing, Joe Pickman paid for it.
Then I love it.
Damn it I wish you didn't have such good taste.
I found the people at the Oscars singularly unattractive, didn't you? I noticed a general decline in facelifts and hair transplants. Must be the economy, don't you think?
I'm out of cigarettes. I can't be expected to give up my daughter and cigarettes in the same day.
If there's one thing i can't stand it's a bi-sexual homosexual. Or is it the other way 'round?
It works either way.
I look as if I've been hit by a bus! A fully loaded, guided tour bus!
How many gin-and-tonics have you had?
Three gins, one tonic.

[admonishingly]
Catch up on the tonics. We don't want to be disgusting tonight, do we?

[shouting]
I am not an asshole!
I've just thrown up on some of the biggest people in Hollywood. Now is no time to be sensitive.
This is an event. It's the first time in my life that I have seen you so nervous.
